title: 103_hr2376
content: The Act may be cited as the "Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians Act". The Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians are descendants of the 1836 Treaty of Washington and the 1855 Treaty of Detroit. The Grand Traverse Band of Ottawa and Chippewa Indians, the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians, and the Bay Mills Band of Chippewa Indians are also recognized as distinct Indian tribes by the Federal Government. The Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians have at least 1,000 eligible members residing close to their ancestral homeland. The Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, with at least 500 eligible members, resides close to their ancestral homeland as recognized in the 1836 Treaty of Washington and 1855 Treaty of Detroit. They filed for reorganization of their tribal government in 1935 under the Indian Reorganization Act. The Bands, including the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, sought reorganization under the Indian Reorganization Act but were denied due to lack of funding. Despite this, they maintained viable tribal governments and formed the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association in 1948. This association successfully pursued a land claim with the Indian Claims Commission between 1948 and 1975. In 1975, the Northern Michigan Ottawa Association petitioned to form a government for the Bands under the Indian Reorganization Act, but the Bureau of Indian Affairs did not act on their request. The United States Government, the government of Michigan, and local governments have had continuous dealings with the recognized political leaders of the Bands since 1836. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Bands" refers to the Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians. The term "member" includes individuals enrolled in the Bands. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. Federal recognition of the Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians is reaffirmed, making them eligible for federal services and benefits provided to recognized Indians. Laws and regulations applicable to Indians in general, including the Indian Reorganization Act, remain in effect for the Bands and their members. The Act reaffirms federal recognition of the Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, making them eligible for federal services and benefits. The Act also designates a service area within 70 miles of the reservations for the Little Traverse Bay Bands for the delivery of Federal services to their enrolled members. The Act reaffirms federal recognition of the Little Traverse Bay Bands of Odawa Indians and the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, making them eligible for federal services and benefits. The Act also designates a service area within 70 miles of the reservations for the Little Traverse Bay Bands for the delivery of Federal services to their enrolled members. Services may be provided to members outside the named service area unless prohibited by law or program regulations. For the Little River Band of Ottawa Indians, certain counties in Michigan are deemed to be within or near a reservation for the delivery of Federal services to enrolled members. Services may be provided to members outside the named counties unless prohibited by law or program regulations. SEC. 5 reaffirms all rights and privileges of the Bands and their members, while SEC. 6 addresses the transfer of land for the Bands' benefit. The Secretary will acquire real property in Emmet and Charlevoix Counties for the benefit of the Little Traverse Bay Bands, and in Manistee and Mason Counties for the benefit of the Little River Band. The Secretary will also accept any real property in those Counties for the Bands if there are no adverse legal claims on the property. The Secretary may acquire additional acreage in the Bands' service area under the Indian Reorganization Act. The land acquired will be held in trust for the Bands and become part of their reservation. SEC. 7. MEMBERSHIP. The Bands must submit membership rolls to the Secretary within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The qualifications for membership will be determined by the Bands' governing documents in consultation with the Secretary. The rolls must be maintained and updated. SEC. 8. CONSTITUTION AND GOVERNING BODY. (a) Constitution.--Within 24 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary will conduct elections by secret ballot for adopting new constitutions for the Bands, following procedures similar to the Indian Reorganization Act. Until new constitutions are adopted, the existing governing documents will serve as interim governing documents for the Bands. (b) Officials.--Within 6 months of adopting constitutions and bylaws, elections for officials will be held. The Bands will adopt constitutions and bylaws and conduct elections by secret ballot to elect officials. Interim governments will be in place until new officials are elected.
